bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Georgetown History Project (GHP) was formed by a group of history enthusiasts in Redding, Connecticut. With the goal of making a documentary film about Georgetown history, the GHP applied for and won a grant from Newman's Own Foundation. Additional funding for the film project came from Georgetown Village Restoration, Inc., Ridgefield Bank, the Weider History Group, other local organizations, and residents. The film was produced by JEM Films and directed by John Maher. Research included more than 30 oral histories, and longtime local residents are featured in the film, including Art Moore, Bertil Rosendahl, and Serena Nazzaro. Also prominently covered are the Gilbert & Bennett Mfg. Co., the 1955 flood, and the construction of Route 107.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Georgetown History Project Collection includes audio-visual materials, correspondence and financial papers relating to the film, transcripts of interviews with local Georgetown residents including Art Moore, Bertil Rosendahl, and Serena Nazzaro, biographies of prominent Georgetown residents, publicity materials, and miscellaneous materials documenting the production of the film from the research through the editing stages.
